title: Creationism, Unchallenged
summary:
Key ideas
- Responsible news organizations are faced with the challenge of reporting on stupid things without giving them too much publicity.
- Studies have shown that the mainstream press has played a role in the dissemination of fake news.
- There is a concern that being too aggressive in covering and debunking fake news might actually give it more attention.
- The author draws a parallel between the coverage of creationism in the early 2000s and the coverage of modern-day fringe ideologies.

Key learnings
- Covering stupid things can result in wasted time and resources and take away from reporting on more important issues.
- Legitimizing unethical practices to combat fringe ideologies may not be effective in the long run.

Key questions
- How can responsible news organizations strike a balance between reporting on stupid things and not giving them too much attention?
- Should mainstream news outlets tone down their coverage of fringe ideologies to avoid signal-boosting them? 
- Is it worth using controversial tactics if it helps to combat anti-science ideologies, or is it just as useless as excessive media coverage of stupid things?
